etymology.description: Pictogram: a child (子) with an open mouth (口) crying; original form of 嗁 ‘to cry’. Arms were removed in bronze inscriptions and the components fused in the modern shape.
etymology.interpretation: Originally depicted a crying child, combining the ideas of ‘child’ and ‘mouth’ to show wailing. Over time, the drawing simplified and the form was repurposed as a sentence-final particle and adverb meaning ‘also/too,’ while the crying sense survived in 嗁.

examples.chinese: 我也是学生(我也是學生)。
他不去(他不去)，我也不去(我也不去)。
examples.pinyin: Tā bù qù, wǒ yě bù qù.
examples.english: He isn’t going; I’m not going either.

examples.chinese: 不仅她会唱歌(不僅她會唱歌)，他也会跳舞(他也會跳舞)。
examples.pinyin: Bùjǐn tā huì chànggē, tā yě huì tiàowǔ.
examples.english: Not only can she sing, he can also dance.
